By most estimates, the 2020 hurricane season was expected to be extremely active. As of 5 October 2020 there have been a total of 25 named storms making it the second most active in history (Mitchell, 2020). Three of the 25 storms (Laura, Teddy, and Delta) qualified as major hurricanes reaching Category 3 strength or more with minimum wind speeds of 111 mph (Chinchar 2020; weather.com, 2020; NOAA, 1999). Averaging one hurricane in October annually, a total of 18 major hurricanes have struck the United States in the month of October since 1851 (Lam & Dolce, 2020, NOAA, 2018). With Hurricane Delta arriving relatively early in the month of October and hurricane season not ending until 30 Nov, there is ample time for additional hurricanes to develop. The most hurricanes to develop in the month of October is 5 which took place in 2010 (Lam & Dolce, 2020). While it becomes more difficult for storms to form later in the season as water temperature begins to drop, it is clearly evident hurricanes can develop in late October. The latest documented landfall of a hurricane taking place on 21 Nov 1985. However, these storms often donâ€™t reach category 3 strength. Utilizing current and historical data estimate the following; 0% chance two or fewer major hurricanes, 90% probability for 3 major hurricanes, 9% probability for four major hurricanes, 1% probability for five, and 0% probability that 6 or more major hurricanes take place in the 2020 hurricane season.

I assess that there will most likely be three (35%) to four (46%) major hurricanes during this hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean. This leaves a 18% chance of five and 5% chance of six or more major storms. The 2020 Atlantic hurricane season will be "extremely active," per the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The hurricane season for 2020 in the Atlantic runs from June 1 to November 30 while the Eastern Pacific hurricane season runs from May 15th to November 30th. The Atlantic basin includes the Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea, and the Gulf of Mexico. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has never forecast 25 storms in a single season, typically only producing 12 named storms in a season. Conditions are more conducive to such storms as water temperature and wind shear as key indicators in predicting the strength of a hurricane season. Both of which are higher than average this year. The amount of available moisture versus the volume of disruptive winds is also a primary indicator. As of 10/7, 25 storms have already been named, with 53 days left in the season. Eight hurricanes have developed this season with three upgrading to a major storm. The three major storms were Laura, Teddy, and Delta. Laura tied the 1856 Last Island hurricane in being the most powerful storm to hit the state of Louisiana. Nine named storms have made landfall within the continental United States. The Greek letter system, resurrected this year, has only been used one other time in 2005. Hurricane Hanna, Isaias, Laura, and Marco have struct the coast in varying degrees, one developing to a category four storm. Total damage is placed over $24 billion with nearly 145 fatalities. Models show that mid-September to November is typically the apex of hurricane activity. Therefore, the season is slowly winding down yet still has the potential to produce another major storm. Thus, three to four major hurricanes will likely occur resulting in a total of four to five major hurricanes for this the entire season, one of the most active on record.
